So yeah I would appreciate it if you would all stand up because I just want to make a point. Thank you. So, how many of you, if you took an antibiotic in the last month would you please sit down today? If you took an antibiotic in the last year would you please sit down? If you took an antibiotic in the last two years would you sit down? And if you can't remember, if you know you took an antibiotic in the last five years when you sit down, and it's it's the best you remember you never took an antibiotic in the last five years, wow. So, healthcare infection prevention control, one of the major pillars of this is about preventing things like antibiotic resistance and antibiotic resistance. And antibiotic resistance it means that the bacterial treating drugs or virus treating drugs that we have resistance means, that they won't work. And the biggest thing that makes them get not work, is having people take them. And we are all guilty in this room, and we're probably really glad that we took them that what we wanna do is we wanna protect our drugs that we use so that they are effective. And so that's one of the key components of healthcare, infection prevention and control. And so that's what this certificate is about, and particularly this certificate was designed for people who want to work in infection as infection preventionists in any kind of health care setting. So you may or may not have heard of an infection preventionist but it's basically like a public health worker on the front lines in hospital and large health care systems, and they do everything public health people do and which makes it a really exciting job. They create policies so that we use, for example antibiotics effectively, but they also create policies about how rooms should be cleaned, about what people can and cannot wear, about whether we take people's temperatures when they visit, they do health education about hand washing or about transmission of infections, and they do a lot of surveillance. They do a lot of data analysis, outbreak investigation, they inspect every piece of equipment that comes that's ordered for the hospital that's a new piece of equipment, to make sure that it can be properly clean. If you ever been has anybody been in the basement of a hospital where they clean the equipment? Yeah, it's a little scary. They have to take every piece of surgical equipment apart and make sure it's properly cleaned, so that we don't get transmission of an infectious agent when they use that instrument on someone else. We've had several outbreaks that have been associated with instruments and that's why when George Bush had to be in the hospital, he bought all new instruments for himself. So infection prevention really includes all kinds of things that you are gonna be learning about as you're here in your master's program. What is surveillance, how you analyze surveillance data, how you write reports, how you detect outbreaks, how you intervene on outbreaks, how you assess risks, how you complying with regulations, how you just basically prevent infections. You use microbiology, you'll interact with laboratory health education, environmental exposures, cleaning disinfection, evaluating new projects, preventing infection during construction, renovation which is a real problem, waste management and also research. So, the other thing that we have is we have a specific internship program associated with this certificate that's competitive. That's these little pictures are of our our students, they were with the work sometimes in different settings, we like to wear the bunny suits. You can see for example the picture, can you see that picture of the bottom we can't really anyway, it's showing how they dispense materials for cleaning instruments in one of the hospitals. And on the left, no you're right they're standing in front of a rodeo clave which is where they take all the waste that can be kid autoclave safely from the hospital. And it's a giant autoclave steam everything where it chops everything up and steams and disinfect it smells really horrible. So we went out of visiting that, so what the particular focus into the range and what someone has an infection prevention is does is specifically to to avoid you getting sick when you come into a hospital. And that's one of the really horrible things is that a lot of infections are acquired while you're in the hospital. And we know that unfortunately a lot of the bacteria that are circulating in the hospital are antibiotic resistance, because if you're in the hospital you much more likely to get an antibiotic. So, I'm not doing this same as everything else, right? This is that one of the nice things we do on the, internship program is not only do you get to visit, if your intern, you get to visit every place that we have an intern. So you get to see compare different health care settings which is really a lot of fun. And this last summer this is a we put on the bunny suits at four different hospitals and saw the differences in how different hospitals handle their cleaning and disinfection, which is of their instruments. And I tell you every hospital is different, so it's it's really an interesting event.
